text: did you know that homegrown peas can be up to 10 times sweeter than store-bought varieties in fact studies show that fresh peas lose their sweetness within hours of being harvested if you want to enjoy the freshest most flavorful peas right from your garden stick around in this video I'll share essential tips and tricks to help you grow a bountiful pea crop ensuring you never have to settle for Bland store bought peas again welcome back to my Channel today we're diving into the wonderful world of pea cultivation whether you're a seasoned Gardener or just starting out growing peas can be a rewarding experience let's get started first off why should you consider growing peas they're not only delicious and versatile in the kitchen but they're also packed with nutrients plus they're a great crop for improving soil Health let's talk about the types of peas you can grow first off why should you consider growing peas let's explore some compelling reasons one nutritional benefits peas are a Powerhouse of nutrition they are rich in vitamins a c and k as well as essential minerals like iron and magnesium plus they're a great source of plant-based protein and fiber making them an excellent addition to a healthy diet two versatility in cooking peas are incredibly versatile you can enjoy them fresh frozen or dried they they can be added to salads soups stir fries and pasta dishes or even blended into smoothies for a nutrient boost their sweet flavor and vibrant color can enhance any meal three soil Health Improvement peas are legumes which means they have a unique ability to fix nitrogen in the soil this process enriches the soil making it more fertile for future crops by growing peas you're not just benefiting yourself you're also improving the health of your garden for years to come four easy to grow peas are one of the easiest crops to grow making them perfect for beginners they germinate quickly and can thrive in cooler temperatures which means you can plant them early in the spring or even in the fall plus they don't require a lot of space making them ideal for small gardens or containers five pest resistance peas are relatively past resistant compared to other crops their growth habit and the fact that they're often planted early in the season help them avoid many common Garden pests this means less time worrying about pests and more time enjoying your garden six sustainable gardening growing your own peas contributes to sustainable gardening practices by cultivating your own food you reduce your carbon footprint and Reliance on store-bought produce which often comes with packaging and transportation emissions seven Family Fun finally growing peace can be a fun family activity kids love to help plant seeds watch them grow and of course enjoy the delicious Harvest it's a great way to teach them about gardening nutrition and the importance of eating fresh homegrown food now that we've covered why you should grow peas let's dive into the different types of peas you can cultivate each type has its unique characteristics and uses so let's explore them in detail one snap peas description snap peas are a delightful hybrid between snow peas and garden peas they have a sweet flavor and a crisp texture making them perfect for snacking harvesting you can eat both the pods and the peas inside and they're best harvested when the pods are plump but still tender uses enjoy them raw in salads stir fried or steamed as a side dish they're also great for adding a crunchy element to various recipes two snow peas description snow peas are flat and have a tender pod that is edible they are harvested before the peas inside fully develop giving them a unique sweet flavor harvesting pick them when the pods are still flat and bright green usually about 2 to 3 in Long uses snow peas are commonly used in Asian Cuisine especially in stir fries and salads their crisp texture adds a refreshing crunch to dishes three Garden peas or shelling peas description Garden peas are the classic variety that most people think of when they hear peas they are round and sweet but the pods are not edible harvesting these peas are best harvested when the pods are full and round but before they become tough you'll need to Shell them to enjoy the sweet peas inside uses Garden peas are perfect for Soups stews and casseroles they can also be M description dried peas are harvested when fully mature and then dried for storage they come in varieties like green and yellow peas harvesting allow the pods to dry on the plant before harvesting once dried the peas can be stored for long periods now that we've discussed the types of peas let's get into the nitty-gritty of planting them proper planting is crucial for a successful pea Harvest so here's what you need to know one timing peas thrive in cooler weather so the best time to plant them is in early spring about 4 to 6 weeks before the last expected Frost in some regions you can even plant them in late summer for a fall Harvest check your local Frost dates to determine the best planting time two soil preparation peas prefer well draining lomy soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0 before planting a mention your soil with compost or well- rotted manure to improve fertility and drainage this will provide the nutrients your peas need to grow strong three planting depth and spacing plant PE seeds about 1 to 2 in deep and space them 2 to 4 in apart in rows that are 18 to 24 in apart if you're planting in a container ensure it's at least 12 in deep to accommodate the root system four watering after planting water the seeds gently but thoroughly to help them germinate keep the soil consistently moist but not water logged once the plants are established they can tolerate some drought but regular watering will promote better growth and yield five support structures depending on the variety some peas may need support as they grow peas and climbing varieties benefit from trellises Stakes or netting install these supports at the time of planting to avoid disturbing The Roots later six mulching applying a layer of mulch around your pea plants can help retain moisture suppress weeds and regulate soil temperature organic mulches Like Straw or shredded leaves work well and will break down over time adding nutrients back into the soil seven companion planting consider planting peas alongside compatible crops like carrots radishes or cucumbers these companions can help deter pests and improve overall Garden Health just be sure to avoid planting peas near them eight fertilization peas are nitrogen fixing plants meaning they can take nitrogen from the air and convert it into a form that plants can use because of this they generally don't require heavy fertilization however a light application of a balanced fertilizer at planting can help boost initial growth especially if your soil is is low in nutrients nine Pest and disease management keep an eye out for common pests like aphids PE Weevil and spider mites you can manage these pasts by introducing beneficial insects like ladybugs or using insecticidal soap if necessary additionally ensure good air circulation around your plants to prevent diseases like powdery mildew 10 thinning once your pea plants have grown a few inches tall thin the if they are too crowded this will allow for better air circulation and reduce competition for nutrients aim for the recommended spacing of 2 to 4 in between plants 11 harvesting as your peas grow keep an eye on them for harvesting snap still tender while Garden peas should be harvested when the pods are full but before they start to turn yellow regular harvesting encourages the plants to produce more pods planting peas is a rewarding experience that can yield delicious results with the right timing soil preparation and Care you'll be on your way to enjoying fresh peas straight from your garden now that your peas are planted let's talk about how to care for them to ensure a healthy and productive crop proper maintenance is key to maximizing your yield and keeping your plants thriving one watering consistent moisture is essential for pea plants especially during their flowering and pots setting stages aim to provide about 1 in of water per week either through rainfall or supplemental watering water deeply to encourage strong root development but avoid overhead watering to minimize the risk of fungal diseases two mulching as mentioned earlier applying a layer of mulch around your pea plants can help retain soil moisture and suppress weeds organic mulches like straw grass clippings or shredded leaves not only provide these benefits but also break down over time enriching the soil three wheed control weeds can compete with your pea plants for nutrients and water regularly check your garden for weeds and remove them by hand or with a hoe be careful not to disturb the roots of your pea plants while weeding four fertilization while peas are nitrogen fixing and generally don't require heavy fertilization you can apply a light dose of a balanced fertilizer or compost tea if you notice slow growth or yellowing leaves avoid High nitrogen fertilizers as they can promote Leaf growth at the expense of pot production five Pest Management keep an eye out for pest regularly inspect the undersides of leaves for signs of pests and take action promptly to prevent infestations six disease prevention to prevent diseases such as powdery mildew ensure good air circulation around your plants by space them properly and avoiding overcrowding if you notice any diseased plants remove them immediately to prevent the spread of infection seven supporting your plants as your pea plants grow they may need additional support if you haven't already set up trellises or Stakes do so carefully to avoid disturbing The Roots peas naturally climb so providing them with a sturdy support use trellises netting or even simple staks to help your plants climb this not only keeps the plants upright but also improves air circulation and makes harvesting easier be sure to check the support regularly and adjust as needed to accommodate the growing plants eight pruning while peas generally don't require much pruning you can remove any yellowing or damaged leaves to promote better air flow and reduce the risk of disease this also helps the plant Focus its energy on producing healthy pods nine monitoring growth regularly check your plants for signs of stress such as wilting discoloration or stunted growth keeping a close eye on your plants will help you catch any issues early and take corrective action 10 harvesting as your peas mature be sure to harvest them regularly for snap and snow peas pick them when they are plump but still tender for garden peas wait until the pods are full but before they start to yellow regular harvesting encourages the plants to produce more pods extending your harvest season 11 as well snow peas are best enjoyed when they are still tender and sweet for garden peas wait until the pods are full and round but before they start to turn yellow this usually occurs about 60 to 70 days after planting depending on the variety the peas inside should be sweet and firm two how to harvest use your fingers to gently pinch the stem just above the Pod to avoid damaging the plant if the pods are particularly tough you can use scissors or garden shears to cut them off be careful not to pull too hard as this can disturb the roots of the plant harvest in the morning when the temperatures are cooler as this helps preserve the sweetness and crispness of the peas three storing your Harvest freshly harvested peas are best enjoyed right away but if you need to store them them keep them in a breathable container in the refrigerator avoid washing them until you're ready to use them as moisture can lead to spoilage for longer storage consider blanching your peas in boiling water for a couple of minutes then plunging them into ice water to stop the cooking process after they cool drain and freeze them in airtight bags this method preserves their flavor and nutrients four encouraging continued production ra regular harvesting is key to encouraging your pea plants to produce more pods the more you pick the more the plants will focus their energy on to wrap up our guide on growing peas let's go over some essential tips for Success that will help you maximize your yield and enjoy a thriving pea Garden one as well snow peas are best enjoyed when they are still tender and sweet for garden peas wait until the pods are full and round but before they start to turn yellow this usually occurs about 60 to 70 days after planting depending on the variety the peas inside should be sweet and firm two how to harvest use your fingers to gently pinch the stem just above the Pod to avoid damaging the plant if the pods are particularly tough you can use scissors or garden shears to cut them off be careful not to pull too hard as this can disturb the roots of the plant harvest in the morning when the temperatures are cooler as this helps preserve the sweetness and crispness of the peas three storing your Harvest freshly harvested peas are best enjoyed right away but if you need to store them keep them in a breathable container in the refrigerator avoid washing them until you're ready to use them as moisture can lead to spoilage for longer storage consider blanching your peas and boiling water for a couple of minutes then plunging them into ice water to stop the cooking process after after they cool drain and freeze them in airtight bags this method preserves their flavor and nutrients four encouraging continued production regular harvesting is key to encouraging your pea plants to produce more pods the more you pick the more the plants will focus their energy on to wrap up our guide on growing peas let's go over some essential tips for Success that will help you maximize your yield and enjoy a thriving pea Garden one choose the right variety selecting the right PE variety for your climate and growing conditions is crucial some varieties are better suited for cooler climates While others thrive in warmer temperatures research and choose varieties that are known to perform well in your area two soil preparation peas prefer well draining lomy soil rich in organic matter before planting amend your soil with compost or well- rotted manure to improve fertility and and drainage a soil pH of 6.0 to 7.0 is ideal for optimal growth three planting depth and spacing plant your PE seeds about 1 to 2 in deep and space them 2 to 4 in apart this allows for good air circulation and reduces competition for nutrients if you're planting in rows space the rows about 18 to 24 in apart to make it easier to access the plants for maintenance and harvesting four watering wisely consistent moisture is key especially during germination and flowering water your peas deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth avoid overhead watering to reduce the risk of fungal diseases instead water at the base of the plants five mulching applying a layer of organic mulch around your pea plants can help retain soil moisture suppress weeds and regulate soil temperature straw grass clippings or shredded leaves work well as mulch materials six companion planting consider planting peas alongside compatible crops like carrots radishes or turnips these plants can benefit from the nitrogen fixed by the pea plants while also helping to deter pests seven Pest and disease management keep an eye out for common pests like aphids and pea weevils introduce beneficial insects like ladybugs to help control pest populations naturally additionally practice crop rotation each year to minimize the risk of soil born diseases eight fertilization continued while peas are nitrogen fixing plants and generally require less fertilizer a light application of a balanced fertilizer at planting can help boost initial growth avoid High nitrogen fertilizers as they can lead to excessive foliage growth at the expense of pot production nine support structures if you're growing climbing varieties of peas provide adequate support with trellises Stakes or netting this not only helps the plants grow upright making harvesting easier but also improves air circulation and reduces the risk of disease 10 regular monitoring keep a close eye on your plants for any signs of stress pests or diseases early detection is key to managing issues before they become serious problems regular Le the leaves and stems for any unusual spots or discoloration 11 harvesting at the right time as mentioned earlier timing your Harvest is crucial for flavor and texture regularly check your plants and harvest peas as soon as they reach the desired size this encourages the plants to produce more pods 12 enjoying your Harvest fresh peas are best enjoyed right after harvesting consider incorporating them into salads stir fries or simply steaming them as a side dish the sweet crisp flavor of freshly picked peas is unmatched 13 learn and adapt every gardening season is a learning experience take notes on what worked well and what didn't and adjust your practices for the next planting engaging with local gardening communities or online forums can also provide valuable insights and tips by following these tips you'll be well on your way to a successful pea Harvest remember gardening is as much about patience and observation as it is about technique happy gardening and there you have it with these tips you'll be well on your way to a bountiful pea Harvest if you enjoyed this video don't forget to like subscribe and hit that notification Bell for more gardening tips what are you planning to grow next let me know in the comments comments below happy gardening and see you next them keep them in a breathable container
